meanings.definition: To take away the virginity of; to deprive of virginity.
meanings.sent1: The cruel man wanted to deflower the innocent girl.
meanings.sent2: It is a serious crime to deflower someone against their will.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous fairy decided to play a prank and deflower all the roses in the garden.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds seemed to deflower the trees, stripping them of their leaves.
meanings.sent5: The evil sorcerer's curse was said to deflower the land, causing crops to wither and die.

meanings.definition: To despoil of beauty, freshness, or purity; to corrupt.
meanings.sent1: The graffiti on the historic building seemed to deflower its grandeur.
meanings.sent2: The factory's pollution continued to deflower the once pristine river.
meanings.sent3: The naughty puppy managed to deflower the neatly arranged flower bed in seconds.
meanings.sent4: The gossip spread through the town like a wildfire, threatening to deflower the reputation of the mayor.
meanings.sent5: The dark clouds seemed to deflower the clear blue sky, signaling an incoming storm.
